name: Unix Tools and Shell Scripting Lab
references: Sumitabha Das, Unix Concepts and Applications, TMH, 4th edition, 2008.
John R Levine, Tony Mason, Doug Brown, Lex and Yacc, Orielly, 2nd edition, 2009.
experiments: Explore different options for the following Unix Commands using man: at, banner, batch, bc, cal, cat, cd, cmp, comm, chmod, chown, chgrp, cp, cron, cut, date, dd, diff, echo, finger, find, ftp, head, kill, lock, ln, ls, lp, lpstat, man, mesg, mkdir, more, mv, nl, nice, passwd, pr, paste, ping, ps, pwd, rcp, rlogin, rmdir, rm, rsh, split, sort, tail, talk, tar, telnet, touch, tput, tr, tty, uname, uniq, wc, who, write
Write shell script for Pattern matching using wild cards, escaping, quoting, iterations, and if then else constructs.
Write shell script for searching for various patterns using grep, pr, head, tail, cut, paste, sort, uniq, and tr.
Write shell script for pattern matching using awk, and sed utilities.
Write shell script for backup using tar and cpio.
Write a make script with dependencies for compiling a static link library/dynamic link library and building an executable to link to such libraries.
Automate make script creation for bigger projects.
Create a project under CVS/git repository and record multiple versions/branches and practice merging of branches.
Debug a C program using gdb to understand core dump of a failed execution.
Write scripts for Simple Distribution of tasks using ssh.
Write scripts for installation of software in multiple machines.
Write scripts for obtaining usage stats memory usage and CPU usage for multiple machines.
A capstone mini project to unify the comprehension of the tools and utilities learnt in this course.
